item.title: Anonymous message to Wall St
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

Directed at anyone who says hard work (even at a low level job) is the way to get to the top.

For someone to get to the top, there has to be someone at the bottom. The person at the top can pull the people at the bottom up but they will most likely not do so. The bottom layer consists of people who have not had an education owing to circumstances beyond/under their control and the upper layer is the manipulative one that exploits the lower layer to get more money, whether they mean them ill or not is something else as you could run a perfectly respectable business with horrible wages for your workers and on the other hand someone else might have different morals and end up getting to the top.

In the end, to go high a bit of luck, opportunity and education is needed, nothing more nothing less.

Read full topic

Bridges are being built now but the parts are being made and shipped over from China, which does nothing for us. Obama can pay big companies all he wants to get them to build a bridge, they’ll do it the safest/cheapest way possible and pocket the rest.

item.title: Anonymous message to Wall St
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

mwiebelhaus:

Directed at anyone who says hard work (even at a low level job) is the way to get to the top. Skip to the next paragraph to avoid story-time.

I’m sure your grandparents are doing very well but I doubt they are even close to the top and that’s what part of the protests are about.

I think the current analogy of a pyramid needs to be changed. The top of the pyramid will represent what is actually achievable, hard work alone won’t get you there but hard work and luck will, hard work alone will simply get you close to the top. How is this different than the current economy? The top of the pyramid should represent the top 10%, but the absolute top 1% isn’t represented on the pyramid, instead it is represented by the god damn stargate style alien spaceship floating ABOVE the pyramid that NO ONE can possibly hope to get to, and that’s where the major inequalities lie.

Read full topic

item.title: Anonymous message to Wall St
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:31, topic:417614”]zyle1992:
Why the people isn’t in power.

  1. The people make their decisions based on facts, media gives them facts.
  2. The media chooses which politicians to give attention, and mold the facts to their liking.
  3. The media depend on money from the rich, therefore they must do as they please.
  4. The rich only depends on people working for them, and buying their stuff. But that isn’t any problem, as ads make sure you always get a demand on useless things. And everyone needs food and work.

The politicians also get money from rich people and in return, they care more about rich business owners than the people. (Mostly republicans)

Your voting system pretty much lock the system into two parties, as starting a new party would only hurt your political views. So the people in power would be those in your two main parties.[/quote]

People don’t make decisions on facts. They make decisions on what they are told are facts.
The people elect the politicians.

(most) Americans always believe the media.

The people still have all the power. They make the decisions on who they want to represent them. Whether the information given to them about those people is factual is up to their discretion. If they feel that it isn’t, they should take it upon themselves to investigate until they are content.

The top 1% pay ~28% of all taxes. The top 10% of that 1% (so 0.1% of all tax payers) pay ~23% of all taxes.

Read full topic

item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

super_:

This stuff is just irritating. The majority of people who consider themselves “apart of Anonymous” are your typical RaNd0M XD freshman in highschool who watched V for Vendetta and has watched Zeitgeist. For example, one of the guys with a Guy Fawkes mask was on the local news for an Occupy Tampa protest, and he didn’t even know what he was doing. He said stupid things like “freedom of equality” and “uhhhhhhhh equal equality”, and his own main incentive for protesting was to “abolish the Fed” because it was devaluing the currency by “printing too much money”.

Not that you are wrong but an idiot in Tampa is like a black person in Africa.

item.title: Anonymous message to Wall St
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:28, topic:417614”]zyle1992: Who has power in US.
Again pick three.
1: Wall-Street.
2: The Democrats and Republicans.
3: Mainstream Media.
4: The people.
Since the people doesn’t have any real power, they can’t be blamed either.
But I totally agree with you about greed, so why base a system on greed?[/quote]

Because greed is the most powerful emotion known to man. If someone has something that you don’t, you’re going to do whatever you can to one-up, or at least match what they have.

Our world would be very different without greed. We are trained from a very young age that people with the most “stuff” have the highest social standing. Humans are very social animals, and as such it is human nature to ALWAYS want more stuff than the next person.

As for who has the power in the US, there is only one group that has power; it is the people.

Read full topic
